comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Google van Tootle ?? - goo.gl/maps/ti0gV - the house with the white chimney behind and below. Best seen from the other side of the footbridge which was presumably built to replace the ferry.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: It was December 1806 before the canal reached Mullingar..................Passengers travelling between Dublin and Mullingar in 1807 were charged 12/6d. for first class and 7/7d. for second class. The duration of the journey was twelve hours. Initially there were two sailings each day in each direction. www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/environment-geography... I would have thought that twelve hours was a good deal.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Nowhere near this end of the canal, but I liked this report in Freeman's Journal on August 18th 1843
CAUTION TO BATHERS Between five and six o'clock yesterday evening, an hour in which the locality is much frequented by the public, two soldiers of the 72nd Highlanders proceeded to bathe in the Royal Canal, Blacquiere Bridge, Circular-road, to the great annoyance of numerous passengers. Mr. Falkner, of Mount Falkner, whose house is next to the place, promptly and most properly at once interfered, and gave the outragers of common decency in custody to the police.
Thank goodness for Mr Falkner.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Greatdown Footbridge (no real info there, unfortunately).

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/30369211@N00] "1 mile and 4 furlongs long" - how quaint, should have said "1 and a half miles long" instead.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: I'd be interested to know how much the canal ferry cost per crossing?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] There are no roads on the far side of the canal, just that house, accessible via the tow path only. It's over a mile to the next bridge, and that bridge is on a backroad. I'm guessing the ferry was made by and for the use of the people who lived in that house to access the main road over the canal.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley/] I agree, that looks homemade to me but what happened to their rope when traffic came by???

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] It's the Royal canal in the 60s! Quote: Word War Two bought a short lived revival of trade to both Royal and Grand Canals but by 1951 the last trader, James Leech of Killucan ceased trading. ... In 1955 Douglas Heard’s “Hark” was the last offically recorded boat to pass through the canal before it’s closure in 1961.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/30369211@N00] Thanks Niall. The very same thought occurred to me - what do they do with the rope when canal traffic must pass? Also, now that you mentioned, it does have a 'home-made' look to it. I know this might sound a bit cynical of me....perhaps they staged this picture and there was no regular ferry crossing there??

The nearest crossing over the canal from that house was about a half mile in either direction.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: O'Dea often seems to have taken pictures of stuff just when it closed, like this one:

comment.author: 66340104@N05
comment._content: Purportedly the cheapest ferry crossing in Europe at one point in time....

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: They just throw the end of the rope over the canal when a boat passes by. It looks about 15 feet to the other side...

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: Give the rope some slack when not ferrying, it sinks (near enough) to the bottom.
